questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department for lower abdominal pain and distension, and difficulty urinating. Two days prior he had knee replacement surgery. After the surgery, a foley catheter was placed and left for two days due to difficulty voiding. He was able to void without the foley catheter prior to discharge. The patient states that he usually wakes up 4 or 5 times during the night to urinate but has not been able to pass urine for over 24 hours since returning home. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37.2°C (100.2°F), heart rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness and distension. There is questionable right costovertebral angle tenderness. Digital rectal exam is significant for a boggy enlarged prostate. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a serum creatinine of 2.9 mg/dL, increased from a baseline of 0.9 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen of 45 mg/dL. White blood count is slightly elevated and urinalysis shows leukocytes and trace blood and is negative nitrates and leukocyte esterase. A foley catheter is placed with minimal urine output. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Abdominopelvic CT scan with IV contrast

questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute kidney injury and evidence of urinary obstruction and a possible urinary tract infection complicated by pyelonephritis. In order to determine if the cause of this patient’s acute kidney injury is from an intrinsic renal or a postrenal cause, renal ultrasound should be performed next.

This patient has a distended tender lower abdomen and an enlarged prostate indicating that he may have urinary obstruction from prostatic hypertrophy causing AKI. However he also has a low-grade fever, mild right costovertebral angle tenderness, and leukocytes in the urine suggesting a UTI, and that he may have complications of a UTI causing AKI. The next best step for determining if the cause of his acute kidney injury is due to intrarenal or postrenal cause is renal ultrasound. It can rule out complications of urinary tract infections, like pyelonephritis and kidney abscess; and it can determine if hydronephrosis is present indicating significant urinary obstruction. Renal ultrasound should be performed to guide the next steps in diagnosis and management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Renal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation:
Incorrect: Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI) due to volume depletion. This patient has no history of blood loss from the surgery and is normotensive.  
❌ Bladder scan:
Incorrect: Bladder scan can be used to determine the level of urinary obstruction, however, renal ultrasound should be performed first in this patient to help determine if the AKI is from intrinsic renal or post-renal causes.  
❌ Abdominopelvic CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: An abdominopelvic CT scan may be helpful for determining if there is pyelonephritis, hydronephrosis, or other complications of infection or urinary obstruction; however because of acute kidney injury, contrast should not be used. Renal ultrasound is a better choice to assess for an intrinsic renal or postrenal cause of AKI.  
❌ Emergent hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is reserved for patients with acute kidney injury and severe hyperkalemia, acidosis, uremia, volume overload unresponsive to diuretics, or certain intoxicants. This patient should be further evaluated for intrinsic vs post renal causes of AKI with a renal ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of increased thirst and urination. Her symptoms started gradually around 2 months ago. Past medical history is notable for cystic acne. She was started on demeclocycline in the last appointment 3 months ago. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows facial acne that has improved from the last visit. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum osmolality  300 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality  195 mOsm/kg 
2 hours after a trial of synthetic ADH administration 
 Serum osmolality  305 mOsm/kg 
 Urine osmolality  201 mOsm/kg 

Based on the results, demeclocycline is discontinued, and the patient is encouraged to follow a low-sodium, low-protein diet. Two weeks later, the patient returns reporting that her symptoms have not improved. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Encourage restriction of daily fluid consumption

questions.solution:
The clinical findings of polydipsia and polyuria in a patient taking demeclocycline should raise the suspicion of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI). The inability to raise urine osmolality after a trial of ADH confirms the diagnosis of nephrogenic DI.  

The first step in the treatment of both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) is similar. It involves starting the patient on a low-sodium, low-protein diet and removing any offending agents. Should conservative measures fail, subsequent interventions will differ depending on which type of DI the patient has. To grasp the treatment rationale, it is important to understand the pathophysiology of each condition.  

The patient in this question has nephrogenic DI, which occurs when the kidney’s V2 receptors are resistant to ADH. Even when exogenous ADH is administered, there is no increase in water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts of the kidney, keeping the urine osmolality low. The next step in treatment involves administering a thiazide diuretic. The diuretic creates a hypovolemic state, which paradoxically increases fluid reuptake in the proximal tubules, ultimately reducing the volume of fluid lost in urine.  

In contrast, central DI occurs when there is inadequate ADH production by the posterior pituitary. In such cases, exogenous ADH administration generally results in a 50% or greater increase in urine osmolality, making desmopressin (synthetic ADH-analog) the treatment of choice.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain abdominal CT:
Incorrect: Pathologies such as polycystic kidney disease and renal amyloidosis can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI). However, the patient’s recent history of demeclocycline use provides a more likely explanation for her symptoms. As a result, an abdominal CT is not indicated at this time. 
✅ Initiate hydrochlorothiazide therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Initiate desmopressin therapy:
Incorrect: Desmopressin is a synthetic ADH analog used in the treatment of central DI. This patient most likely has nephrogenic DI. Desmopressin is rarely used to treat nephrogenic DI and is indicated only when other treatment options, such as thiazide or potassium-sparing diuretics, have failed.
❌ Encourage restriction of daily fluid consumption:
Incorrect: Fluid restriction may be recommended for patients with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Individuals with SIADH have low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality. In contrast, this patient has an elevated serum osmolality and reduced urine osmolality, which is consistent with DI. Fluid restriction is not indicated for patients with DI as it may exacerbate their dehydration.
❌ Initiate lithium therapy:
Incorrect: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder and may cause nephrogenic DI as a side-effect. Lithium has no role in the management of either central or nephrogenic DI.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to confusion and lethargy for the past 3 days. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and a 50-pack year smoking history. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears somnolent but is arousable to voice. Laboratory studies reveal a serum calcium level of 14.6 mg/dL and a normal creatinine. A chest x-ray shows a solitary mass in the right middle lung. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Begin radiation therapy for lung cancer

questions.solution:
With a 50-pack year smoking history, this patient presents with confusion, lethargy, and severe hypercalcemia >14 mg/dL. These findings, in the setting of a solitary mass in the right middle lobe on chest x-ray suggest hypercalcemia of malignancy, likely caused by squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. The first-line management is hydration with IV 0.9% saline to restore intravascular volume and increase urinary calcium excretion.    

Acute management of hypercalcemia focuses on two key principles: lowering serum calcium levels and addressing the underlying cause. Isotonic saline should be administered, as hypercalcemia frequently results in volume depletion due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and volume depletion can exacerbate hypercalcemia by reducing renal calcium excretion. In severe hypercalcemia, intravenous (IV) isotonic saline, subcutaneous calcitonin, and an IV bisphosphonate (zoledronic acid) should be administered simultaneously. Saline and calcitonin can reduce serum calcium concentrations within 12 to 48 hours, while bisphosphonate will be effective a few days later, but can provide a more long-term effect. Following stabilization, focus should shift to treating the underlying cause, which can range from primary hyperparathyroidism to malignancy-related hypercalcemia.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous 0.9% saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Begin radiation therapy for lung cancer:
Incorrect: The immediate management of severe hypercalcemia involves lowering calcium levels with administration of intravenous isotonic saline. Treatment for lung cancer can be considered once the patient is stabilized.  
❌ Obtain a TSH level:
Incorrect: This patient with a 50-pack year smoking history and mass seen on chest x-ray likely has hypercalcemia of malignancy.  The severe hypercalcemia should be treated immediately. Further workup for causes of hypercalcemia including checking TSH for hyperthyroidism should be done if there are signs of hyperthyroidism or the underlying cause of hypercalcemia is unclear.  
❌ Begin chemotherapy for lung cancer:
Incorrect: The immediate management of severe hypercalcemia involves lowering calcium levels with administration of intravenous isotonic saline. Chemotherapy for lung cancer can be considered once the patient is stabilized and the diagnosis is confirmed.  
❌ Obtain a parathyroid hormone level:
Incorrect: A parathyroid hormone level can aid in diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism; however, this patient's clinical presentation and lung mass strongly suggest malignancy-associated hypercalcemia. Parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) should be checked and will likely be elevated confirming the underlying cause of hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 1-week history of nausea, vomiting, and constipation. She reports associated muscle weakness and fatigue. She has not had fevers, chills, or abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension that is well-controlled with ramipril, as well as gastroesophageal reflux disease that she has been managing by taking over-the-counter antacids multiple times a day. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 126/79 mmHg, pulse is 86/min, respiratory rate is 18/ min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, she appears tired with dry mucous membranes. She has mild bilateral proximal muscle weakness and normal reflexes. Which of the following electrolyte disturbances is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with nausea, vomiting, constipation, muscular weakness, evidence of dehydration, and fatigue. Given the patient’s history of excessive antacid intake, she likely has hypercalcemia due to milk-alkali syndrome. Many antacids contain calcium, which, when taken in excess, can lead to hypercalcemia, especially in the context of renal insufficiency or concurrent use of certain medications such as ACE inhibitors or thiazide diuretics.    

Hypercalcemia is a condition characterized by elevated levels of serum calcium, with symptoms that can range from subtle to severe, depending on the degree of calcium elevation, and the rate at which this increase occurs. Acute and severe hypercalcemia can result in cardiac conduction abnormalities, coma, and potentially death. Chronic, mild hypercalcemia may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.    

Hypercalcemia can affect multiple organ symptoms and patients can present with a variety of symptoms. These include nephrolithiasis, bone pain, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and neuropsychiatric disturbances ranging from fatigue to confusion and even coma. Other signs and symptoms include proximal muscle weakness, band keratopathy from corneal calcium deposition in chronic cases, and cardiac abnormalities such as a shortened QT interval on ECG, bradycardia, and heart block.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hypercalcemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypocalcemia typically results in neuromuscular irritability, including symptoms and signs such as tetany, paresthesia, and muscle cramps, which are not observed in this patient. Given the patient's history of excessive antacid use, hypercalcemia is the most likely cause.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Hyponatremia can lead to lethargy and nausea, it is also frequently associated with headaches, seizures, and altered mental status in severe cases. The history of excessive use of antacids and the presence of constipation and muscle weakness are more suggestive of hypercalcemia.  
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Patients with hyperkalemia typically present with arrhythmias or EKG changes, as well as nonspecific symptoms such as weakness and fatigue. This patient’s history of excessive use of antacids and the presence of constipation and muscle weakness are more suggestive of hypercalcemia.  
❌ Hyperphosphatemia:
Incorrect: Patients with hyperphosphatemia typically experience muscle cramps, tetany, and perioral numbness or tingling. It is commonly caused by tumor lysis syndrome and renal failure not by antacid use.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of constipation, frequent urination, and abdominal discomfort for one week. She has been experiencing an intermittent dry cough and occasional joint pain for the past 4 months. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination is significant for hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals a serum calcium of 12.8 mg/dL. A chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen in this patient?  



Picture taken fromwikimedia commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of hypercalcemia including constipation, polyuria, and abdominal discomfort. She also has had dry cough and joint pain for months and is found to have hepatosplenomegaly on examination and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray. Sarcoidosis is the most likely cause of her hypercalcemia, and an increased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D level will most likely be seen.  

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology characterized by non-caseating granulomas. It frequently involves the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes, skin, and liver. Patients exhibit symptoms such as cough, dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, and joint pain. Hypercalcemia can occur in patients with sarcoidosis due to unregulated production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (active vitamin D) by macrophages within the granulomas. This leads to increased intestinal absorption of calcium and hypercalcemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level  :
Incorrect: The angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) level is typically elevated in patients with sarcoidosis.   
❌ Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH):
Incorrect: Elevated PTH levels are indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism, which can present with hypercalcemia and related symptoms. In this patient with cough, joint pain, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray, the most likely cause of hypercalcemia is sarcoidosis.  
❌ Decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH):
Incorrect: Decreased TSH levels are seen in hyperthyroidism, which may cause hypercalcemia. However, the absence of symptoms of hyperthyroidism and the presence of a cough, joint pain, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray suggest sarcoidosis as the likely cause.  
❌ Increased parathyroid hormones related-protein (PTHrP) level:
Incorrect: PTHrP can be produced by some malignant tumors and can cause hypercalcemia of malignancy. This patient's signs and symptoms (e.g., dry cough, joint pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy) are suggestive of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden-onset weakness that started two hours ago. The patient has experienced two similar episodes that each resolved within one hour. However, today, the patient was unable to get out of bed and continued to be weak for 2 1/2 hours, prompting the patient to call an ambulance. The patient has experienced about six months of heat intolerance, palpitations, anxiety, and weight loss. On physical examination, the patient is noted to be thin and diaphoretic. The patient is alert and oriented and appears anxious. The patient’s skin is warm to the touch, and the patient has thinning hair. There is flaccid paralysis of the lower extremities as well as decreased strength in the proximal arms. Distal arm strength is normal without fatigability. Reflexes are diminished throughout. Laboratory studies are notable for a serum potassium of 2.1 mEq/L. Which of the following laboratory results would be consistent with the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing leg paralysis and proximal arm weakness in association with severe hypokalemia. Additionally, the patient has had several months of symptoms consistent with hyperthyroidism (e.g. heat intolerance, palpitations, weight loss). The patient has evidence of muscle weakness and thyrotoxicosis on examination. Thus, thyrotoxic periodic paralysis is the most likely diagnosis. This would be associated with a low TSH and elevated T4.   

There are many potential causes of hypokalemia. Often, this can be elicited from the history and presentation (e.g. decreased potassium intake, recent GI illness, diuretic use). If the cause is not obvious, additional workup can be obtained. This should start with obtaining a serum magnesium level to rule out hypomagnesemia. From there, patients should be evaluated for potential causes of transcellular potassium shifts. This should include reviewing medications (e.g. theophylline, beta agonists, insulin) and evaluating for conditions like hyperthyroidism, which may be accompanied by symptoms (e.g. heat intolerance, palpitations) and a low TSH.    

Periodic paralysis (PP) is a muscle disease where patients experience episodes of muscle weakness that can last from hours to days. When patients are also hypokalemic during these episodes of muscle weakness and are found to have symptoms and evidence of thyrotoxicosis, then thyrotoxic periodic paralysis can be diagnosed.  

If these causes are ruled out, the next step is to obtain urine studies in order to calculate a urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio. If this ratio is ≤ 1.5, extrarenal potassium wasting is most etiology, which can be caused by laxative overuse, other causes of severe diarrhea, or excessive sweating. If the ratio is > 1.5, then a condition causing renal potassium wasting is likely. In patients with hypertension or evidence of hypervolemia, consider diseases affecting mineralocorticoid activity, such as Cushing syndrome, hyperaldosteronism, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia. If no cause is found, the next step is to check the patient’s acid-base status. Metabolic acidosis is associated with renal tubular acidosis and acetazolamide use. Metabolic alkalosis is associated with Bartter and Gitelman syndrome as well as diuretics.  



Option Analysis

✅ Low TSH and high T4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low magnesium:
Incorrect: Hypomagnesemia can cause hypokalemia. However, severe hypomagnesemia is typically associated with seizures, tetany, and hyperreflexia. This patient is not exhibiting these but has evidence of thyrotoxicosis.  
❌ Elevated urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio:
Incorrect: An elevated urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be seen in renal potassium wasting syndromes. This patient’s signs and symptoms are more concerning for thyrotoxic periodic paralysis.  
❌ Positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen with myasthenia gravis, which can also cause proximal limb weakness. However, this patient does not demonstrate the typical muscle fatigability on examination.  
❌ Elevated creatine kinase:
Incorrect: Rhabdomyolysis can result in muscle weakness but more commonly results in muscle pain. Additionally, it is more often associated with hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room from a nursing home to evaluate confusion and lethargy. The group home supervisor states she had no fever, cough, or recent fall. Her past medical history includes major depressive disorder, hypertension, and SLE. Her current medications include venlafaxine, amlodipine, and cyclophosphamide. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. She appears lethargic with incoherent speech. Physical examination reveals moist mucous membranes, and no neurological deficits are appreciated. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The leucocyte count is 5,000/mm3. Additional laboratory findings are demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum Sodium   126 mEq/L 
 Serum osmolality   260 mOsm/kg H20 
 Urine osmolality   500 mOsm/kg H20  
 Urine sodium   60 mEq/L

choices.text: Switch to another class of antidepressants
Free water restriction and 0.9% normal saline infusion

questions.solution:
This patient with altered mental status, hyponatremia, and urine osmolality > serum osmolality has a presentation consistent with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). SIADH can occur secondary to multiple insults, including CNS or lung pathology (malignancy), antidepressants like fluoxetine, and antiepileptics like carbamazepine or phenytoin. In addition, chemotherapeutic agents like cyclophosphamide have been shown to induce SIADH.  

Cyclophosphamide is nitrogen mustard that acts as an alkylating agent. Other nitrogen mustards include mechlorethamine and ifosfamide. Cyclophosphamide is indicated in treating solid organ tumors, leukemia, and lymphomas. It is also used to treat rheumatic disorders such as SLE, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and microscopic polyangiitis. Its mechanism of action involves the creation of cross-links between interstrand guanine bases of DNA, resulting in DNA damage and impairment of replication and repair.   Cyclophosphamide is associated with additional adverse effects, including alopecia, GI disturbances, myelosuppression, hemorrhagic cystitis, gonadal toxicity, infertility, and teratogenic effects.  

Hyponatremia due to SIADH is characterized by low serum osmolality (<275 mOsm/kg H20), high urine osmolality (>100 mOsmol/kg H20) and high urine sodium (>40 mEq/L). Treatment of SIADH includes free water restriction and administration of IV 0.9% normal saline when neurologic symptoms are also present.  









Option Analysis

❌ Administer lisinopril :
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, indicated in the treatment of left ventricular dysfunction. Congestive cardiac failure can be associated with dilutional hypervolemic hyponatremia; however, this patient does not have evidence of volume overload.  
❌ Switch to another class of antidepressants:
Incorrect: Although antidepressants like fluoxetine can cause SIADH, venlafaxine belongs to a different class of antidepressants called SNRIs, which are not known to induce SIADH. Switching to another antidepressant would not be the most appropriate next step in management. 
❌ Administer desmopressin :
Incorrect: Desmopressin is an ADH analog that is the treatment of choice in central diabetes insipidus. Diabetes insipidus results from a deficiency of ADH or lack of response to ADH. This condition presents low urine osmolality and hyponatremia in contrast to SIADH, which results in high urine osmolality, high urine sodium, and hyponatremia. Administration of desmopressin for this patient would worsen her electrolyte imbalance. 
❌ Administer hydrochlorothiazide :
Incorrect: Hydrochlorothiazide results in loss of sodium and water. It is not indicated in the treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia. 
✅ Free water restriction and 0.9% normal saline infusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
